summary: This is an FBI News Briefing dated October 20, 2020, summarizing major news stories across categories including leading news, counter-terrorism, counter-intelligence, criminal investigations, financial crime, cyber division, law enforcement services, other FBI news, and other Washington and international news. The document covers a wide range of topics such as US charges against Russian intelligence officers for cyberattacks, the Hunter Biden laptop controversy, COVID-19 developments, election security, and various criminal investigations.

persons.name: David Bowdich
persons.context: Quoted in the document regarding US charges against six Russian intelligence officers for cyberattacks, stating Russia will not abide by accepted norms.

persons.name: Scott Brady
persons.context: Mentioned in connection with the indictment of Russian officers for cyberattacks, noting Heritage Valley Health System spent $2 million to repair damage.

persons.name: Michael A. Christman
persons.role: FBI Pittsburgh Special Agent in Charge
persons.context: Quoted praising the teams tracking members of the GRU involved in cyberattacks.

persons.name: Frank William Robertson Perry
persons.context: A Maryland man described by the FBI as a member of the anti-government 'boogaloo' movement, pleaded not guilty to a gun charge.

persons.name: Richard Trask
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of the Whitmer kidnapping plot investigation, stating the FBI was hindered by encrypted apps.

persons.name: Ahmed Luqman Talib
persons.context: An Australian-based businessman sanctioned by the Trump administration for helping Al Qaeda move money internationally via gemstones.

persons.name: John Ratcliffe
persons.context: Stated there is no evidence Hunter Biden's laptop is part of a Russian disinformation campaign, contradicting Adam Schiff.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: Accused by Ratcliffe of politicizing intelligence by suggesting Hunter Biden's laptop is part of a Russian disinformation campaign.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: Central figure in the controversy over emails allegedly found on his laptop, with debates over their authenticity and potential Russian disinformation.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Reportedly provided the Hunter Biden laptop story to Fox News, which initially passed on it due to credibility concerns.

persons.name: Mark Meadows
persons.context: Appeared on Fox News, suggested Democrats are spreading disinformation about the Hunter Biden laptop and that more damaging information is to come.

persons.name: Ted Cruz
persons.context: Predicted Facebook and Twitter face 'potentially serious campaign finance violations' for censoring stories unfavorable to Democrats.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Reported to be under fire in the run-up to the election, facing pressure from Trump allies to disclose information damaging to Joe Biden.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Featured throughout the briefing on various topics: Sudan terrorism list removal, calling Fauci 'a disaster', Hunter Biden allegations, election comments.

persons.name: Anthony Fauci
persons.context: Criticized by President Trump as 'a disaster' and part of 'these idiots' regarding coronavirus response.

persons.name: Scott Atlas
persons.context: Reported to have consolidated power over pandemic response, sidelined other task force members, and advanced fringe theories.

persons.name: Lisa Montgomery
persons.context: A woman convicted of strangling a pregnant woman and kidnapping her unborn child, scheduled to be executed on December 8.

persons.name: Michael Horowitz
persons.context: Discussed the growing threat of drones for prison smuggling operations.

persons.name: Amy Coney Barrett
persons.context: Subject of Senate confirmation process, with Senate working over weekend to complete her confirmation.

persons.name: Gavin Newsom
persons.context: Announced California will 'independently review' FDA-approved COVID vaccines before releasing them.

persons.name: Andrew Cuomo
persons.context: May lift restrictions on some COVID red zones, facing disapproval from Catholic leaders over attendance limits at houses of worship.

persons.name: E. Jean Carroll
persons.context: Filed a defamation lawsuit against President Trump for denying her rape allegation; DOJ argues Trump was acting in official capacity.

persons.name: Alexei Navalny
persons.context: Called on President Trump to condemn his attempted assassination, which he claims was orchestrated by Putin's people.

persons.name: Evo Morales
persons.context: His party claimed victory in the Bolivian presidential election through his handpicked successor, Luis Arce.

persons.name: Lucas Vinyard
persons.context: One of two officers who surrendered to face manslaughter charges in the shooting of unarmed motorist Bijan Ghaisar.

persons.name: Alejandro Amaya
persons.context: One of two officers who surrendered to face manslaughter charges in the shooting of unarmed motorist Bijan Ghaisar.

persons.name: Bijan Ghaisar
persons.context: Unarmed motorist shot and killed by U.S. Park Police officers after a chase; officers charged with manslaughter.

connections.description: Ratcliffe accused Schiff of politicizing intelligence regarding the Hunter Biden laptop story.
Trump criticized Fauci as 'a disaster' and part of 'these idiots' regarding coronavirus response.
Giuliani provided the Hunter Biden laptop story to media, pushing allegations about Hunter Biden's foreign business dealings.
Trump made repeated references to alleged communications between Hunter Biden and foreign officials to damage Joe Biden's campaign.
Both U.S. Park Police officers charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of Bijan Ghaisar.
Atlas reportedly sidelined other doctors on the coronavirus task force, including Fauci, and advanced conflicting theories.
Carroll sued Trump for defamation after he denied her rape allegation; DOJ intervened arguing Trump was acting in official capacity.

events.title: US Charges Six Russian Intelligence Officers
events.description: The US charged six Russian intelligence officers with launching cyberattacks, including NotPetya malware, targeting Ukrainian power grid, 2018 Olympics, French elections, and others, causing nearly $1 billion in losses.

events.title: Hunter Biden Laptop Controversy
events.description: Ongoing controversy over emails allegedly from Hunter Biden's laptop, with DNI Ratcliffe stating no evidence of Russian disinformation, while Adam Schiff suggested otherwise.

events.title: Trump Calls Fauci 'A Disaster'
events.description: President Trump criticized Dr. Anthony Fauci and other health experts as 'idiots' and 'a disaster' in a conference call with campaign staff.

events.title: US Park Police Officers Surrender
events.description: Two U.S. Park Police officers, Lucas Vinyard and Alejandro Amaya, surrendered to face manslaughter charges in the 2017 shooting death of unarmed motorist Bijan Ghaisar.

events.title: Supreme Court Allows Pennsylvania Ballot Extension
events.description: The Supreme Court allowed Pennsylvania to count mail-in ballots received up to three days after the election, rejecting a Republican plea.

events.title: Scheduled Execution of Lisa Montgomery
events.description: Lisa Montgomery, convicted of strangling a pregnant woman and kidnapping her unborn child, is scheduled to be executed via lethal injection.

events.title: Early Voting Begins in Florida
events.description: Early voting began in Florida, with long lines reported despite rain, as over 2.5 million Floridians had already voted by mail.

keyFacts: The US charged six Russian intelligence officers (GRU) with cyberattacks including NotPetya malware, causing nearly $1 billion in losses and targeting the Ukrainian power grid, 2018 Olympics, and French elections.

DNI John Ratcliffe stated there is no intelligence evidence that Hunter Biden's laptop is part of a Russian disinformation campaign, contradicting claims by House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff.

President Trump called Dr. Anthony Fauci 'a disaster' and referred to coronavirus health experts as 'idiots' during a campaign call, escalating his criticism of the nation's top infectious disease expert.

Two U.S. Park Police officers surrendered to face manslaughter charges for the 2017 shooting death of unarmed motorist Bijan Ghaisar, after a state investigation followed a federal decision not to pursue civil rights charges.

The Supreme Court allowed Pennsylvania to count mail-in ballots received up to three days after the election, rejecting a Republican challenge, in a 4-4 decision that left a state court ruling in place.
